Legal_Issue: Validity of Patent No. 2,209,735 for use of atomoxetine to treat ADHD
Evidence_Assessment: MGH Study was too small and short-term to prove clinical utility; lack of disclosure of factual basis for sound prediction
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies on prior art and sufficiency of evidence
Legal_Rule: Patent must demonstrate utility, novelty, and non-obviousness; utility requires demonstrated effectiveness or sound prediction
Grounds_for_Claim: Obviousness, anticipation, lack of disclosure, inutility
Outcome_on_Merits: Patent found invalid due to inutility
Key_Evidence_Considered: MGH Study, expert testimony, prior art
Applicant_Challenge: Novopharm challenged the validity of Lilly's patent
Court_Result: Patent invalidated under Section 60(1) of the Patent Act
Defendant_Response: Lilly defended the validity of the '735 Patent
Evidence_Type: Clinical study data, expert opinion, patent documentation
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Inutility, lack of sound prediction, insufficient disclosure
Governing_Rule: Patent Act requirements for utility, novelty, and non-obviousness
